titleStmt.title: Plasticity in the Olfactory Cortex Is Enabled by Disinhibition of Pyramidal Neuron Apical Dendrites

analytic.title: Plasticity in the Olfactory Cortex Is Enabled by Disinhibition of Pyramidal Neuron Apical Dendrites

biblStruct.note: Received May 10, 2022; revised July 1, 2022; accepted July 12, 2022.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: The brain encodes and stores information by creating neuronal ensembles.
These ensembles can be formed through longterm potentiation (LTP) of synapses between coactivated neurons.
Because inhibitory interneurons suppress the activity of other neurons, they can regulate LTP induction by limiting coactivation.
Importantly, neurons can be disinhibited if they are targeted by inhibitory interneurons, which themselves are silenced by other inhibitory interneurons.
Such disinhibition is present in many brain regions and can gate LTP induction (Letzkus et al., 2015).

Although different types of interneurons can engage in disinhibition (Kullander and Topolnik, 2021), the most often and best described disinhibitory circuit in the cortex involves presynaptic vasointestinal-peptide-expressing (VIP 1 ) interneurons and postsynaptic somatostatin-expressing (SST 1 ) interneurons (Pi et al., 2013).

Because SST 1 interneurons mainly target the apical dendrites of excitatory pyramidal neurons (Wang et al., 2004), strong inhibition of SST 1 interneurons by VIP 1 interneurons leads to disinhibition of the apical dendrites.

This can open a window for synaptic integration, linking different information streams, namely, inputs to apical dendrites and inputs to basal compartments of excitatory neurons, thus allowing the induction of associative LTP.
In the olfactory anterior piriform cortex (APC), odors are encoded by distributed neuronal ensembles created by synaptic potentiation (Stettler and Axel, 2009).

Previous studies have shown that LTP in APC pyramidal neurons is induced when these neurons receive different inputs at the same time: strong stimulation of excitatory inputs synapsing at distal branches of pyramidal neuron apical dendrites combined with weak stimulation of excitatory intracortical inputs arriving at proximal dendrites resulted in LTP at proximal synapses only when GABA A receptors (GABA A Rs) were blocked (Kanter and Haberly, 1993).
This indicates that locally recruited inhibitory inputs usually prevent LTP; however, whether LTP in APC is gated by disinhibitory circuits has yet been elusive.
To answer this, Canto-Bustos et al. ( 2022) investigated the role of different inhibitory interneuron classes and the effect of disinhibition on plasticity induction in the APC.

To examine the precise targets of inhibition, Canto-Bustos et al. ( 2022) applied a GABA A R antagonist focally along the pyramidal neuron apical dendrite and recorded baseline EPSPs during extracellular electrical stimulation of the intracortical pathway.
To induce plasticity, proximal stimulation was paired with strong stimulation near the distal dendrites in APC, activating afferents from mitral and tufted cells of the olfactory bulb.

Consistent with previous work (Kanter and Haberly, 1993), synaptic potentiation occurred only when a GABA A R antagonist was present and only at proximal synapses, leaving synaptic strength at distal synapses unaltered.

These findings indicate that APC ensembles that encode specific odors might emerge through the strengthening of intracortical synapses, which requires simultaneous strong activation of distal excitatory inputs and the absence of inhibitory input along the apical dendrite.
To identify possible sources of LTPpreventing inhibition, Canto-Bustos et al. ( 2022) examined the roles of different interneuron subclasses.

In particular, they investigated SST 1 interneurons and parvalbumin-expressing (PV 1 ) interneurons, both of which can be recruited by and also target local pyramidal neurons, thus providing recurrent inhibition (Silberberg and Markram, 2007;Suzuki and Bekkers, 2012).

When either SST 1 interneurons or PV 1 interneurons were silenced using optogenetic techniques, paired electrical stimulation of inputs to distal and proximal dendrites of pyramidal neurons led to LTP in proximal synapses.
A modest increase of pyramidal neuron firing rate was also observed during optogenetic silencing of either interneuron class.
These results suggest that local inhibition involving SST 1 and PV 1 interneurons suppresses LTP induction in pyramidal neurons of APC.
Consequently, suppressing SST 1 and PV 1 interneuron activity may open a window for associative synaptic plasticity.
Canto-Bustos et al. ( 2022) hypothesized that VIP 1 interneurons play a disinhibitory role in this circuit.
Using mice in which VIP 1 interneurons expressed channelrhodopsin, the authors recorded postsynaptic events in all known VIP 1 interneuron targets during optogenetic excitation of VIP 1 interneurons.
VIP 1 interneurons were frequently connected to SST 1 and PV 1 interneurons as well as pyramidal neurons, but they produced only weak inhibition in PV 1 interneurons and pyramidal neurons.
In contrast, VIP 1 interneurons strongly inhibited SST 1 interneurons, delaying spike initiation and decreasing spike rates.

These results suggest the presence of a disinhibitory mechanism in which VIP 1 interneuron activity suppresses SST 1 interneuron-mediated inhibition, which targets the apical dendrites of pyramidal neurons.

To investigate whether this disinhibitory circuit promotes LTP at intracortical pyramidal neuron synapses, LTP induction experiments were repeated while VIP 1 interneurons were optogenetically activated.
Similar to the effects found during SST 1 interneuron silencing, EPSP amplitudes and rise times were significantly enhanced after LTP induction during optogenetic VIP 1 interneuron excitation.
During LTP induction, pyramidal neuron firing rates also increased to frequencies similar to those found during optogenetic SST 1 interneuron suppression.

In summary, Canto-Bustos et al. ( 2022) confirmed that LTP in proximal synapses of APC pyramidal neurons can be induced only if pyramidal neurons receive intracortical and long-range excitatory inputs and while inhibitory input is suppressed.
Furthermore, the authors showed that the required suppression of inhibition can be mediated by VIP 1 interneurons.
Thus, they described a disinhibitory learning mechanism that can facilitate ensemble formation of pyramidal neurons encoding odor identity in the APC.
The study adds the olfactory cortex to the list of brain regions where a VIPmediated disinhibitory circuit has been shown to promote learning by releasing inhibition from excitatory neurons.

Other areas where such circuitry has been described are somatosensory (Williams and Holtmaat, 2019), motor (Adler et al., 2019), visual (Zhang et al., 2014), auditory, and medial prefrontal cortex (Pi et al., 2013) as well as hippocampus (Turi et al., 2019).

Canto-Bustos et al. ( 2022) argue that precise timing of VIP 1 interneuron activation is crucial to open a time window for associative LTP; however, the source of this activation in APC remains unclear.
In other brain regions, VIP 1 interneuron activity is modulated, for example, by cholinergic input from the basal forebrain (Alitto and Dan, 2012).
Cholinergic neurons are thought to be recruited on novel or salient stimuli, and their activity can promote learning in their target brain areas (Poorthuis et al., 2014).
APC also receives cholinergic inputs (Fletcher and Chen, 2010) with its exact neuronal targets yet unknown.

However, similar to the effect that Canto-Bustos et al. ( 2022) have shown when optogenetically activating VIP 1 interneurons, the application of a cholinergic agonist to piriform cortex slices also has been shown to suppress inhibition and is sufficient to obtain associative LTP (Patil et al., 1998).

Hence, the sensation of a salient or novel odor could lead to coactivation of the cholinergic system together with the olfactory system, and cholinergic modulation of APC neurons could promote the formation of stable odorencoding ensembles by driving disinhibition in APC.
Whether cholinergic inputs indeed target VIP 1 interneurons in APC has yet to be investigated.
Another input to APC origins from the amygdaloid complex, a brain area associated with emotion and fear learning (Majak et al., 2004).

Particularly projections from the posterior cortical nucleus and the lateral nucleus of the amygdala, both participating in reproductive and ingestive behavior and processing pheromonal information could be of relevance for precise and stable odor learning.
In APC, projections from primary olfactory areas and the amygdaloid complex converge.
Thus, it is possible that the strength of odor-encoding ensembles in APC is dependent on its emotional relevance.

This could occur via the recruitment of local disinhibitory circuits by amygdaloid projections, opening a window for LTP induction and thus leading to robust encoding of the emotionally relevant odor.
Again, it is yet to be tested whether VIP 1 interneurons are targets of projections from the amygdaloid complex.
For future work, it would be therefore crucial to identify brain areas that target VIP 1 interneurons in APC to get a better understanding of how and when neural odor ensembles are formed.

In addition, it is important to examine in vivo the LTP induction mechanisms, which are arguably in conflict with mechanisms obtained from work performed in vitro (Inglebert et al., 2020;Gonzalez et al., 2022).

Thus, it would be interesting to investigate whether the disinhibitory circuit described by Canto-Bustos et al. ( 2022) is also relevant for odor learning in vivo, as has been shown for example in hippocampus where VIP 1 interneuronmediated disinhibition has behavioral relevance during reward location remapping of place cell ensembles (Turi et al., 2019).
To better understand the effect of disinhibition on learning and the formation of neural ensembles, computational models could be used.

The mapping of odor components onto neurons in the APC in a distributed, nontopographic fashion already resembles common architectures of neural network models, which also feature distributed encoding of inputs (Masquelier and Kheradpisheh, 2018).
Additionally incorporating inhibitory circuits into such models could help to further explore how disinhibition assists the formation of ensemble representation.
Results from such models could then be used to design experiments investigating the biological implementation further; in particular, learning rules used to establish neuronal ensembles.

In summary, Canto-Bustos et al. ( 2022) convincingly demonstrated that a disinhibitory circuit motif involving VIP 1 and SST 1 interneurons can gate associative LTP in APC pyramidal neurons, a mechanism that has been described in many other brain areas and that could facilitate the emergence of distributed stimulusencoding ensembles in APC.
• J. Neurosci., August 24, 2022 • 42(34):6484-6486 Loidl and Abs Disinhibition in Olfactory Cortex
